perturbation.original_text: Royalty payments shall be paid quarterly within thirty (45) days following the close of the calendar quarter.
perturbation.changed_text: Royalty payments shall be paid annually within ninety (180) days following the close of the calendar year.
perturbation.explanation: Modifying the payment terms to be annually and within 180 days directly contradicts standard business practice that suggests payments should be paid quarterly, at the minimum, and also goes against accounting standards and practices that suggest annual reconciliation
perturbation.contradicted_law: Standard accounting and auditing regulations; Potential breach of fiduciary duty

perturbation.original_text: Subject to a written advance notice of thirty (30) calendar days, all relevant records supporting the preparation of the Reports shall be made available during normal business hours for inspection at the expense of Licensor by Licensor or by a selected representative of Licensor for the sole purpose of verifying the Reports and the accuracy of the payments made or due to Licensor under this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: Subject to a written advance notice of five (5) calendar days, all relevant records supporting the preparation of the Reports shall be made available only between 9:00 AM and 10:00 AM for inspection at the expense of Licensor by Licensor or by a selected representative of Licensor for the sole purpose of verifying the Reports and the accuracy of the payments made or due to Licensor under this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the advance notice to 5 days and limiting the inspection time to a one-hour window imposes an unreasonably short timeframe for the Licensee to prepare for and accommodate an audit.  Most companies need ample time to compile data for an audit. This is contradictory to generally accepted auditing principles that ensure reasonable access and preparation time.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of contract, Potential violation of auditing standards

perturbation.original_text: If Licensee is the Breaching Party and fails to cure the default within sixty (60) calendar days upon receipt of the Notice of Default, the Licensor has the right to terminate this Agreement with immediate effect by written notice ("Notice of Termination") to the Breaching Party.
perturbation.changed_text: If Licensee is the Breaching Party and fails to cure the default within fifteen (15) calendar days upon receipt of the Notice of Default, the Licensor has the right to terminate this Agreement with immediate effect by written notice ("Notice of Termination") to the Breaching Party.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period to 15 days is an unreasonable short amount of time. Also, this short amount of time contradicts generally accepted contract law principles that allow reasonable time for remedies.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles of reasonable time for cure
